content.description: Crank the initial starting moves of Saturn Sheets, then move left and climb the steepening face between Planet Y and Saturn Sheets.

climbs.name: Saturn Sheets
climbs.fa: (TR) Todd Swain & Peggy Buckey, November 1989,  FL: Jeff Rhoads & Andy Brown, November 1989

content.description:
Climb an easy ramp up to the base of a headwall and then climb large edges to a very high first bolt (a fall before the first bolt would be bad). Once the first bolt is reached well protected thin edges/smears lead up and right to another bolt near the southwest arete which is then followed to the summit of the formation.

Good climbing but the lack of protection at the start makes this a climb only for those not leading at their limit. One star out of five.
content.location: West face of the Planet X Pinnacle, right of Planet Y is this all bolted route that is not a sport climb.

content.description:
Start above a cactus and climb a steep, juggy hand crack until it narrows to thin hands, then fingers and then finally dies out at a bolt. Clip the bolt and make some face moves using patina edges and smears to reach up and left to a short flared crack that leads to the summit.

Enjoy the view of the surrounding desert - Saddle Rocks, Headstone Rock, The Astro Domes, King Dome/Hall of Horrors and the Loose Lady Buttress are some of the formations visible from the summit of this formation, and then rap off the west face from anchors atop the route Planet Y. Two stars out of five.
content.protection: Gear to 2.5", bolt (3/8"), bolted rap anchor (3/8")
content.location:
The route

Planet X

takes a nice line up the south face of the eponymous pinnacle via a nice crack and it's typically the first route encountered when approaching the formation.

climbs.name: Planet Claire
climbs.fa: Dave Evans, Todd Swain, Todd Gordon & Dave Levy, September 1990

content.description:
Planet Claire features challenging blunt arete squeezing and pressing to start out of the catsclaw on standard issue Josh oatmeal, before moving up and left spiral staircase style following a line of good holds on increasingly better rock to the top of the pinnacle.

This route featured surprisingly fun moves, and would be better but for lack of traffic which has the lower half of the route in pretty gritty shape.
content.protection: 6 bolts, the 5 lead bolts are all buttonheads (5/16") and there is one 3/8" bolt at the start of the route.  The route is fully bolted, but this is Joshua Tree.
content.location: On the Planet X pinnacle, starts on the blunt arete 15' left of Planet Y.

content.description:
Climb the heavily featured crack until it dies out, where a combination of sidepulls and grainy edges gains a bolt which protects a long move to a visibly flexing flake the size of a hardcover book...gingerly pull down and not out on the flake and make the final moves to the anchors.

A fun climb with some intricate movement that's easily toproped from the anchors if you don't feel like leading it. Worth doing if only to witness firsthand the amazing elasticity of the local quartz monzonite as evidenced by the fragile, flexing flake. One star out of five.
content.protection: Gear to 3 inches, 1 bolt (5/16"), bolted anchor/rap (3/8")
content.location: This route is on the west face and climbs a crack to face leading directly to the rappel anchors for the formation.

content.description: The face between Planet X and Planet Z.
content.location:
The face between

Planet X

and Planet Z.
